Award.AwardTitle: CAREER: Giant Planets in Dusty Disks
Award.AbstractNarration:
The influence of dust grains on growing planets and their host disks extends far beyond providing seed material for planet cores. Grains determine the disk vertical structure, disk evolution rate, and dominant planet formation mechanism. The PI and her team will incorporate dust settling and grain growth into a time-evolving protostellar disk model and use the model to test three hypotheses relating to the influence of dust on planet formation. First, grain growth and settling, by lowering the scale height of the protostellar disk, may restrict planets forming by core accretion to sub-Jupiter masses. Second, grain growth and settling may trigger gravitational instability in a disk that was previously stable by increasing the disk's transparency to its own radiation. Third, olivine grain opacity increases with iron abundance and decreases with magnesium abundance in the mid-infrared, where the disk radiates heat generated by viscous turbulence. The dominant planet formation mechanism may depend on the [Mg/Fe] ratio of the star-disk material.

The PI will translate her research on planet formation into educational enrichment for first-year college students by starting the New Orbits program, a cohort of 20 students each year who will form a learning community centered on planetary science. The New Orbits program is designed to help incoming students feel confident in their ability to pursue a career in science. New Orbits students will attend a weekly seminar with the PI and take astronomy and geology classes together each semester to fulfill their general science requirement while learning the basics of planetary science. The capstone of the New Orbits program will be a yearly field trip to McDonald Observatory to learn about historic and ongoing planetary research at the 82 inch telescope.

POR.DRECONTENT:
How do planets form, and what's the best way to find them? Research funded by this NSF grant has uncovered a new formation pathway for supergiant planets, paved the way for observational astronomers to accurately measure the amount of mass available for planet formation, and developed new tools for planet hunters to validate discoveries of earthlike planets. Here I outline the findings of NSF CAREER grant 1520101, Giant Planets in Dusty Disks.

 

When my group started research, it was unclear whether gas in disks orbiting young stars could form planets by suddenly collapsing under its own gravity. While many calculations suggested that such a collapse was possible, some astronomers pointed out that the masses of nearby planet-forming disks were too low for the collapse to be likely. Our exploration of the chemical behavior of the carbon monoxide (CO) molecule, which is often used to measure disk mass, showed that observations of CO were being misinterpreted: disk mass measurements failed to take into account destruction of CO by cosmic rays and X-rays. In reality, disk masses are much higher—probably by a factor of 10!—than the original CO measurements suggested, paving the way for planet formation by gravitational collapse.

 

Next we demonstrated that electrostatic sticking of dust in planet-forming disks could actually trigger the collapse of gas into supergiant planets. To understand the behavior of space dust, think of what you see when you vacuum under your bed: tiny bits of dust stick together, forming larger and larger dust bunnies. In fact, dust bunnies are critically important for planet formation: they are the bottom rungs of a growth ladder that eventually leads to planets like Mars, Earth, and Jupiter. (The solar system does not contain any planets that formed “top-down” by direct gravitational collapse of gas—all of our planets have their humble origins in the dust.) But according to calculations I published before the start of this grant, bottom-up planet formation does not work for the supergiant planets on wide orbits of other stars that were first observed in 2008, with many more to follow. Work funded by this grant showed that when tiny grains coalesce to form dust bunnies, planet-forming disks are better able to cool off by emitting infrared light. Since only cool gas can suddenly collapse to form supergiant planets, electrostatic dust sticking is just as important for top-down planet formation as for bottom-up growth! It’s extraordinary that dust, which accounts for only 1% of the mass available for planet formation, nevertheless has control over the entire process.

 

In other work on supergiant planets, my colleagues and I showed that several Y dwarfs—failed stars with temperatures more reminiscent of Florida beaches than the sun’s surface—have many characteristics in common with supergiant planets, such as mass and occurrence rate. The Y dwarfs’ motion through space is more random than that of brown dwarfs with higher masses and temperatures, suggesting a different origin story than the typical brown dwarf. From a growth perspective, supergiant planets are somewhere between planets and stars, with a starlike formation pathway in an environment that typically forms planets. In a closely related project, my group showed that a massive star orbited by a red dwarf may have the same “in-between” formation mechanism as a sunlike star orbited by a supergiant planet.

 

Finally, though planet origin stories are always compelling, one of the primary goals of astronomy in the 21st century is to find “Earth 2.0”—an extrasolar planet with a climate capable of hosting earthlike life. Unfortunately, searches for habitable planets are plagued by false positives: discoveries of “planets” that later turn out to be parasitic signals caused by gas motion at the star surface. Trying to discover earthlike planets pushes both technology and statistics to their absolute limits, as the speeds of gas bubbles near the star surface can be 1000 times higher than the speed of a star’s motion in response to the gravitational tug of a planet. One way we can verify planet discoveries is to monitor wavelengths of light that highlight activity from the star’s magnetic fields, which can cause velocity signals that mimic planets. My students and I discovered 32 new wavelengths of light that are sensitive to star magnetism, dramatically increasing the number of tools available to astronomers who are trying to sort out planets from noise.
